name: NewYorker
text: “This is a potential public health disaster,” an infections-disease doctor wrote, of TestUtah’s attempt to disrupt coronavirus testing in the state. A pandemic, he said, “is not the time for amateurs to learn.” https://t.co/FRvOqqslA0

name: NewYorker
text: The writer, cook, and artist Tunde Wey discusses his recent essay, “Don’t Bail Out the Restaurant Industry,” and his radical vision for a more equitable culinary world. https://t.co/nPKZnvK0KI

name: NewYorker
text: By following provisions of the Mineral Leasing Act of 1920, a North Dakota company may come to control a large swath of Utah’s federal land. “The law itself is the crime—a gift to the oil and gas businesses,” @billmckibben writes. https://t.co/CIxJD3IXOy

name: NewYorker
text: Spike Lee’s new film, “Da 5 Bloods,” pulls the traumas of black men’s experiences of the Vietnam War out of obscurity and puts them in the forefront of political consciousness. https://t.co/gBMJxOMdb9

name: NewYorker
text:
What if celebrity social-media platforms were treated less like public-relations opportunities and more like the powerful communication channels and resource vectors that they are?

text: The message of the guidelines released by the Trump Administration on Friday was amplified by its appearance on the anniversary of the largest mass murder of queer people in U.S. history. https://t.co/BRQsfhbmXW

name: NewYorker
text: The big-risk-big-reward ethos of startups is fuelled by venture capitalists who know that they won’t be the ones to go broke. https://t.co/YmByZRyhYn

name: NewYorker
text: With relatively few exceptions, the armed forces have hewed to the rule that they should never be deployed against American citizens. But President Trump has shown himself willing to trash any institution that he can’t bend to his will. https://t.co/4krc2juhLW

name: NewYorker
text: “My days were structured around food. If I ate the right thing at the right time, I was fine, but if I didn’t, I wasn’t, and most of the time I wasn’t, because most of the time I didn’t.” A Personal History by @burtonsusan. https://t.co/kuMXQcmnLy

name: NewYorker
text: A group of Utah tech companies signed contacts worth more than $80 million to launch coronavirus testing initiatives in four states. Are they delivering accurate results? https://t.co/bHdEPlKUo0

text: Republican voters and members of Congress have thoroughly embraced Trumpism, but the President’s recent actions are causing a rift in the Party that is changing the dynamics of the 2020 campaign. https://t.co/mh0an0Q7GN

name: NewYorker
text: The chaotic, angry, deﬁant tableaux in the streets of Minneapolis, Seattle, New York, Atlanta, and beyond represent a reckoning, a kind of American Spring, one long in the making and ignited not just by a single police killing, @jelani9 writes. https://t.co/Lrh6P8Zn8H

name: NewYorker
text: Take a closer look at Nelson’s latest cover, which depicts how the murder of George Floyd embodies the history of violence inflicted upon black people in America. https://t.co/p0ceeCsLMR

text: The basic principle of Modern Monetary Theory is seductively simple: governments don’t have to budget like households because, unlike households, they can simply print their own money. https://t.co/JrwT5D2wK6

text: Within their borders, Heather Glazzard’s FaceTime portraits show all the tools used to make them: a computer with 68-per-cent battery remaining, a rectangular application window, two faces on either end of an Internet connection. https://t.co/iqAHhpGU1j
